title: General Knowledge Quiz VIII (50 Questions)
description: Challenging but fair. New categories: Language & Etymology, Inventions & Discoveries, Philosophy & Religion, Environment & Ecology, Exploration & Cartography.

items.q: The word 'robot' was popularized by which 1920 play by Karel Čapek?
items.a: R.U.R. (Rossum’s Universal Robots) - introduced 'robot' from Czech 'robota' (forced labor)

items.q: Which ancient seafaring people spread an influential 22‑letter abjad?
items.a: The Phoenicians - script that influenced Greek and Latin alphabets

items.q: What is a sentence that uses every letter of the alphabet at least once called?
items.a: A pangram - e.g., 'The quick brown fox jumps over the lazy dog'

items.q: Who designed the first widely known set of emoji in 1999?
items.a: Shigetaka Kurita - 176 pixel icons for NTT DoCoMo in Japan

items.q: What do linguists call a word formed from the initial letters of a phrase (e.g., NASA)?
items.a: An acronym - pronounced as a word (vs. initialism like FBI)

items.q: What is the study of word origins and historical development called?
items.a: Etymology - traces how meanings and forms change over time

items.q: Which punctuation mark is used to indicate possession or contractions?
items.a: The apostrophe - also used for omitted letters

items.q: What is the most widely spoken Romance language by native speakers?
items.a: Spanish - evolved from Vulgar Latin on the Iberian Peninsula

items.q: What is the official language regulator for modern French?
items.a: Académie française - founded in 1635 to standardize French

items.q: Which writing direction do Arabic and Hebrew primarily use?
items.a: Right‑to‑left - with contextual letter shaping

items.q: Who discovered penicillin in 1928?
items.a: Alexander Fleming - antibiotic effect observed in a contaminated culture

items.q: Who patented the telephone in 1876?
items.a: Alexander Graham Bell - US patent 174,465 granted March 7, 1876

items.q: Which two scientists pioneered the CRISPR‑Cas9 gene‑editing method?
items.a: Emmanuelle Charpentier & Jennifer Doudna - landmark 2012 paper

items.q: Who invented the World Wide Web in 1989–90?
items.a: Tim Berners‑Lee - proposed HTTP, HTML, and the first web server/browser

items.q: Which engineer developed the first practical incandescent light bulb in 1879?
items.a: Thomas Edison - commercialized long‑lasting carbon filament bulbs

items.q: Which mathematician invented the mechanical calculator known as the Pascaline?
items.a: Blaise Pascal - 1640s adding machine for his tax‑collector father

items.q: What medical imaging technique uses strong magnets and radio waves?
items.a: MRI (magnetic resonance imaging) - non‑ionizing cross‑sectional scans

items.q: Which German physicist discovered X‑rays in 1895?
items.a: Wilhelm Röntgen - first Nobel Prize in Physics (1901)

items.q: What battery type powers most smartphones today?
items.a: Lithium‑ion - high energy density, rechargeable chemistry

items.q: Which early computer scientist wrote the 1936 paper that defined a universal machine?
items.a: Alan Turing - conceptual foundation of modern computing

items.q: Which text of Confucianism is a collection of sayings compiled by disciples?
items.a: The Analects - central source of Confucius’s teachings

items.q: Which Hindu scripture is a dialogue between Arjuna and Krishna?
items.a: The Bhagavad Gita - part of the Mahabharata

items.q: What is the method of questioning associated with Socrates?
items.a: The Socratic method - probing dialogue to test ideas

items.q: Which ethical theory is associated with Jeremy Bentham and John Stuart Mill?
items.a: Utilitarianism - actions judged by overall happiness produced

items.q: Which Buddhist teaching outlines suffering and its cessation?
items.a: The Four Noble Truths - core doctrine leading to the Eightfold Path

items.q: Which religion’s holy book is the Guru Granth Sahib?
items.a: Sikhism - scripture compiled by the Sikh Gurus

items.q: Which Islamic month involves fasting from dawn to sunset?
items.a: Ramadan - ninth month of the Islamic lunar calendar

items.q: What is the Jewish day of rest observed from Friday evening to Saturday evening?
items.a: Shabbat (Sabbath) - day of rest and spiritual renewal

items.q: Which branch of philosophy studies knowledge and justified belief?
items.a: Epistemology - examines the nature and scope of knowledge

items.q: What is the term for the belief that God and the universe are identical?
items.a: Pantheism - philosophical/theological view equating God with nature

items.q: What is the world’s largest coral reef system?
items.a: The Great Barrier Reef - World Heritage site off Queensland, Australia

items.q: What term describes species found only in a particular region?
items.a: Endemic - restricted to a specific geographic area

items.q: Which gas is the primary driver of long‑term anthropogenic warming?
items.a: Carbon dioxide (CO₂) - potent greenhouse gas from fossil fuels

items.q: What process converts atmospheric nitrogen into usable forms for plants?
items.a: Nitrogen fixation - by lightning and nitrogen‑fixing microbes

items.q: What biome is characterized by permafrost and low‑growing vegetation?
items.a: Tundra - cold, treeless regions at high latitudes/elevations

items.q: Which international agreement aims to limit global warming to well below 2 °C?
items.a: The Paris Agreement - UNFCCC accord adopted in 2015

items.q: What do we call the variety of life at genetic, species, and ecosystem levels?
items.a: Biodiversity - enhances resilience and ecosystem services

items.q: Which renewable energy source uses moving air to turn turbines?
items.a: Wind power - converts kinetic energy into electricity

items.q: What is the major cause of ocean acidification?
items.a: Absorption of CO₂ - lowers seawater pH affecting marine life

items.q: What is the main layer of the atmosphere where weather occurs?
items.a: The troposphere - lowest layer containing most atmospheric mass

items.q: Who completed the first circumnavigation of the Earth after Magellan’s death?
items.a: Juan Sebastián Elcano - captained Victoria to Spain in 1522

items.q: Which map projection was introduced by Gerardus Mercator in 1569?
items.a: Mercator projection - preserves rhumb lines for navigation

items.q: Through which London site does the Prime Meridian pass?
items.a: Royal Observatory, Greenwich - defined as 0° longitude

items.q: Who reached the South Pole first, in December 1911?
items.a: Roald Amundsen - Norwegian explorer who beat Scott’s party

items.q: Which mountain is named after Surveyor General Sir George Everest?
items.a: Mount Everest - official name adopted in 1865 by the RGS

items.q: Which expedition reached the Pacific Ocean in November 1805?
items.a: Lewis & Clark Expedition - at the mouth of the Columbia River

items.q: What is the name of Earth’s galaxy supercluster containing the Local Group?
items.a: Laniakea - vast gravitational basin mapped in 2014

items.q: Which explorer’s 1492 voyage led to sustained European contact with the Americas?
items.a: Christopher Columbus - voyage under Spanish crown

items.q: What navigation instrument determines direction relative to Earth’s magnetic poles?
items.a: Magnetic compass - aligns with Earth’s magnetic field

items.q: Which island‑studded sea lies between Sweden and Finland?
items.a: The Baltic Sea’s Gulf of Bothnia - northern arm of the Baltic
